<p><strong>Discretionary spending</strong> in some retail categories plummeted by <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/how-chinese-consumers-are-changing-shopping-habits-in-response-to-covid-19">as much as 90 percent</a> at the peak of COVID-19 lockdown efforts aimed at easing the spread of the virus. Given that discretionary spending comprises roughly one-fifth to one-fourth of many countries’ GDP, we sought to understand how consumers in the most populous countries in Asia—China, India, and Indonesia—are thinking about such expenditures, as portions of these economies begin to reopen. Between April 28 and May 10, 2020, we surveyed more than 3,600 consumers across 91 cities about their pre- and midpandemic purchases and postpandemic plans in a broad range of categories, including apparel, personal electronics, domestic appliances, and vehicles.<sup>1</sup></p>
<p>At the time the survey was conducted, these countries were in different stages of the pandemic’s progression and economic reopening. Yet the survey findings point to shifts seen across them, which could remain in place long after the public-health crisis ends. These shifts will require retailers to make strategic changes—and in some cases, accelerate the changes they have already made in response to the crisis.</p>
<h2>Key insights</h2>
<p>Overall, the survey results suggest there is cautious optimism in the surveyed countries. Yet while about two-thirds of respondents in India and Indonesia expected to recover income or savings lost during the lockdown by the end of the year, many respondents in each of the three countries surveyed are planning to delay or forego bigger-ticket purchases, seeking to find better value, and strengthening their desire to purchase from brands they trust. At the same time, some are grappling with guilt about spending in more conspicuous categories. Meanwhile, responses show an accelerating intent to use digital channels while visiting physical stores to experience products.  </p>
<h3>1. Ticket size matters</h3>
<p>Respondents were more likely to indicate plans to indefinitely postpone or cancel purchases for bigger-ticket items such as jewelry, vehicles, and home construction or renovation than for smaller ones. Fifty percent of Chinese respondents and 61 percent of Indonesian respondents who, before the outbreak, planned to buy cars said that they will forego those purchases this year, and 59 percent in China and 39 percent in Indonesia said the same about planned jewelry purchases. By comparison, just 13 percent of Chinese respondents and 7 percent of those in Indonesia said they are delaying or canceling plans to purchase skincare items.</p>
<p>Notably, Indian respondents were less likely than those elsewhere to say that they would forego their purchases at this point—a sentiment that could change should economic conditions decline.</p>
<h3>2. Value polarization</h3>
<p>As with the 2008 global financial crisis, the survey results suggest that the outbreak may affect consumers’ thinking about price and quality, with increased price sensitivity and more careful consideration of nonessential spending. However, our research illustrates how multifaceted the concept of value truly is.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The findings show that many consumers expect to reduce spending this year. </p></blockquote></div>
<p>First, the findings show that many consumers expect to reduce spending this year. Among respondents in China and India planning to complete purchases in a variety of categories later this year, roughly one in three stated that they intend to spend less than originally planned. However, respondents made a distinction between price and value. Among Chinese respondents planning to shop for small domestic appliances, for instance, the share citing “multipurpose” as one of the top three attributes or factors they consider when making purchasing decisions increased by ten percentage points compared with before the outbreak. That share is four times larger than the share who said low prices were a top consideration.</p>
<p>Yet the findings also suggest that for a subset of consumers, loosening lockdown restrictions could lead to a surge in spending. Among Indonesian apparel shoppers, for example, higher-spending respondents (who said they typically spend about $200 or more per month on clothing) had a 40 percent net intent to spend more in the future than they did before the outbreak,<sup>2</sup> compared with 4 percent among those who said they typically spend about $10 to $50 per month. We see similar findings for skincare, where those who spend upward of $350 per year on skincare were roughly twice as likely as respondents who spend less to say that they planned to increase spending in the future. </p>
<h3>3. Preference for trusted brands</h3>
<p>Across countries and segments, respondents commonly cited “trusted brand” as a top consideration in their purchasing decisions, along with purchases being a good value for the money. Among respondents, market-leading brands retained significantly higher conversion rates—60 percent to 70 percent—than did other brands.</p>
<p>Even among those planning to spend less than initially intended on a purchase, up to 60 to 80 percent in each country said that their preference is to stay with their intended brand—albeit by actively looking for a discount or promotion, or by switching to a cheaper product within the brand. This brand loyalty seems to be especially true for categories such as consumer durables. For example, 78 percent of Indonesians planning to spend less on their mobile-phone purchases want to stay with their preferred brand, compared with 45 percent of apparel shoppers.</p>
<h3>4. Uneasiness and guilt</h3>
<p>Amidst the uncertainty of the continuing global crisis, our survey findings suggest there might be a feeling of guilt associated with discretionary spending, even among those who can afford it—particularly for some more conspicuous categories. Although respondents consistently cited uncertainty over the crisis’s impact on their income as the top reason for planning to trade down or forego purchases, one-third of Chinese mobile-phone shoppers cited feelings of guilt as their reason for doing so. Similarly, one in five Indian consumers who planned to trade down or forego purchases of large domestic appliances said their main reason was that it didn’t feel right to spend, given the current social context. It remains to be seen whether this sentiment will change in the coming months. </p>
<h3>5. Digital shopping accelerated, but physical stores retain appeal</h3>
<p>The COVID-19 crisis has naturally shifted consumers toward digital shopping and engagement channels. Yet the findings show uneven rates of acceleration across various types of online channels. Responses suggest that multicategory online marketplaces could be poised to gain the most momentum in the coming months, with the largest increase in net usage intent of any channels tested in the survey. But significantly larger shares of respondents in India and Indonesia said they expect to increase their use of their preferred platforms after the COVID-19 pandemic than said the same about other online platforms.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Responses suggest that multicategory online marketplaces could be poised to gain the most momentum in the coming months.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>At the same time, respondents also expressed the desire to return to physical stores—particularly to shop for apparel in Indonesia, and mobile phones and small and large domestic appliances in India. In India, we see a higher stated intent to visit exclusive-brand stores than multibrand stores. </p>
<h2>Implications for businesses</h2>
<p>Thriving in the post-COVID-19 future will ultimately require changes in how companies in these sectors think about staying relevant to consumers while managing increased operational complexity as well as potential delays in the rebound of demand and customer traffic. Combined with sales migration toward online channels and the renewed focus on value, these changes could contribute to margin compression. Moreover, there are certain behaviors that are likely to shift fundamentally, requiring reconsideration of the consumer proposition and companies’ go-to-market strategy and operating model. Based on our research, there are five actions that companies can take now to prepare for the next normal.</p>
<p><strong><em>1. Don’t just reopen: Rethink your store</em></strong></p>
<p>Companies have already invested significant time and effort to enforce new safety protocols and operating procedures as lockdowns ease. However, online acceleration will require a fundamental reevaluation of the role that stores still play for consumers in the next normal and how to ensure a delightful experience. Survey responses show that shoppers appreciate the “touch and feel experience” of physical stores. As stores enable product interaction while also generating traffic for e-commerce sales, the traditional way of looking at individual-store profit-and-loss statements might need to change. Also, it is important to consider how this role can be accomplished with a <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-stores-for-retails-next-normal">simplified and more flexible store operation</a>.</p>
<p>This entails reimagining end-to-end consumer engagement on digital channels and seamlessly linking online and offline experiences to radically accelerate in-store omnichannel integration. Companies that are both digital and offline, rather than one or the other, will be better positioned in the days ahead—especially if they can use both to create a mutually reinforcing customer ecosystem. </p>
<p><em><strong>2. Earn and maintain consumers’ trust</strong></em> </p>
<p>The survey results indicate a “flight to safety” toward trusted brands, potentially accentuated by an environment of uncertainty and inability to test or experience products before buying them. Moreover, with the COVID-19 crisis affecting incomes and savings, respondents seem to be more cautious in their brand choices. Companies with high brand scores can further grow their presence and business by communicating reliability and instilling further trust in the brand. For new and niche players, communicating reasons to trust, and ensuring a “first-time right” product experience, could become more important than ever.  </p>
<p><strong><em>3. Radiate value</em></strong></p>
<p>As shoppers look to purchase items that meet their criteria for value, it will be paramount for businesses to be able to immediately communicate to visitors to an online channel or store how their products fulfill these criteria. This entails rethinking which “star products” to highlight, as well as reconsidering overall product assortment and promotional calendars to effectively lower the customer hurdle by highlighting relevant products and offers, and by offering accessible entry price points. As we saw earlier, however, the concept of “value” can differ significantly by segment. Hence, executing this well requires a strong understanding of customer segmentation that enables a personalized approach. </p>
<p>Finally, as consumers search for the best deals—and retailers face overstock from lockdowns—companies can benefit from being nimble amid a heightened promotional environment. Doing so may require adopting a rapid “test and learn” approach so they can quickly pivot to determine the most compelling offers for various customer segments.</p>
<p><strong><em>4. Follow the consumer</em></strong></p>
<p>In our research, we saw consumers interacting with multiple channels and touchpoints, such as official brand websites, social commerce, online platforms, exclusive-brand stores, and multibrand stores. As consumers use more channels, it is important for companies to ensure that their experiences at each touchpoint are consistent, generate delight, and further enhance companies’ understanding of consumers. This requires brands and companies to not only be open to shifting their marketing messages but also investing in analytics capabilities and reallocating financial and talent resources as needed.</p>
<p><em><strong>5. Communicate purpose</strong></em></p>
<p>In previous <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/purpose-shifting-from-why-to-how">consumer-research efforts</a>, we have seen that customers and employees appreciate brands that exhibit a social purpose and communicate honestly about how the crisis has affected their service levels and overall business. As companies prepare for what comes next, they may need to rethink and adjust their marketing tone and message to reflect consumers’ new reality, given the social context and consumption guilt that could affect some purchases. </p>

Stephanie Chan, Mahima Chugh, \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bcbc63b40-12e7-425b-9c68-30ba85e4acb4%7d%40en\"\u003eFelix Poh\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/our-people/simon-wintels\"\u003eSimon Wintels\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDiscretionary spending\u003c/strong\u003e in some retail categories plummeted by \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/how-chinese-consumers-are-changing-shopping-habits-in-response-to-covid-19\"\u003eas much as 90 percent\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;at the peak of COVID-19 lockdown efforts aimed at easing the spread of the virus. Given that discretionary spending comprises roughly one-fifth to one-fourth of many countries\u0026rsquo; GDP, we sought to understand how consumers in the most populous countries in Asia\u0026mdash;China, India, and Indonesia\u0026mdash;are thinking about such expenditures, as portions of these economies begin to reopen. Between April 28 and May 10, 2020, we surveyed more than 3,600 consumers across 91 cities about their pre- and midpandemic purchases and postpandemic plans in a broad range of categories, including apparel, personal electronics, domestic appliances, and vehicles.\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the time the survey was conducted, these countries were in different stages of the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s progression and economic reopening. Yet the survey findings point to shifts seen across them, which could remain in place long after the public-health crisis ends. These shifts will require retailers to make strategic changes\u0026mdash;and in some cases, accelerate the changes they have already made in response to the crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKey insights\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, the survey results suggest there is cautious optimism in the surveyed countries. Yet while about two-thirds of respondents in India and Indonesia expected to recover income or savings lost during the lockdown by the end of the year, many respondents in each of the three countries surveyed are planning to delay or forego bigger-ticket purchases, seeking to find better value, and strengthening their desire to purchase from brands they trust. At the same time, some are grappling with guilt about spending in more conspicuous categories. Meanwhile, responses show an accelerating intent to use digital channels while visiting physical stores to experience products.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Ticket size matters\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRespondents were more likely to indicate plans to indefinitely postpone or cancel purchases for bigger-ticket items such as jewelry, vehicles, and home construction or renovation than for smaller ones. Fifty percent of Chinese respondents and 61 percent of Indonesian respondents who, before the outbreak, planned to buy cars said that they will forego those purchases this year, and 59 percent in China and 39 percent in Indonesia said the same about planned jewelry purchases. By comparison, just 13 percent of Chinese respondents and 7 percent of those in Indonesia said they are delaying or canceling plans to purchase skincare items.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotably, Indian respondents were less likely than those elsewhere to say that they would forego their purchases at this point\u0026mdash;a sentiment that could change should economic conditions decline.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Value polarization\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs with the 2008 global financial crisis, the survey results suggest that the outbreak may affect consumers\u0026rsquo; thinking about price and quality, with increased price sensitivity and more careful consideration of nonessential spending. However, our research illustrates how multifaceted the concept of value truly is.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, the findings show that many consumers expect to reduce spending this year. Among respondents in China and India planning to complete purchases in a variety of categories later this year, roughly one in three stated that they intend to spend less than originally planned. However, respondents made a distinction between price and value. Among Chinese respondents planning to shop for small domestic appliances, for instance, the share citing \u0026ldquo;multipurpose\u0026rdquo; as one of the top three attributes or factors they consider when making purchasing decisions increased by ten percentage points compared with before the outbreak. That share is four times larger than the share who said low prices were a top consideration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYet the findings also suggest that for a subset of consumers, loosening lockdown restrictions could lead to a surge in spending. Among Indonesian apparel shoppers, for example, higher-spending respondents (who said they typically spend about $200 or more per month on clothing) had a 40 percent net intent to spend more in the future than they did before the outbreak,\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e compared with 4 percent among those who said they typically spend about $10 to $50 per month. We see similar findings for skincare, where those who spend upward of $350 per year on skincare were roughly twice as likely as respondents who spend less to say that they planned to increase spending in the future. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Preference for trusted brands\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross countries and segments, respondents commonly cited \u0026ldquo;trusted brand\u0026rdquo; as a top consideration in their purchasing decisions, along with purchases being a good value for the money. Among respondents, market-leading brands retained significantly higher conversion rates\u0026mdash;60 percent to 70 percent\u0026mdash;than did other brands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven among those planning to spend less than initially intended on a purchase, up to 60 to 80 percent in each country said that their preference is to stay with their intended brand\u0026mdash;albeit by actively looking for a discount or promotion, or by switching to a cheaper product within the brand. This brand loyalty seems to be especially true for categories such as consumer durables. For example, 78 percent of Indonesians planning to spend less on their mobile-phone purchases want to stay with their preferred brand, compared with 45 percent of apparel shoppers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Uneasiness and guilt\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmidst the uncertainty of the continuing global crisis, our survey findings suggest there might be a feeling of guilt associated with discretionary spending, even among those who can afford it\u0026mdash;particularly for some more conspicuous categories. Although respondents consistently cited uncertainty over the crisis\u0026rsquo;s impact on their income as the top reason for planning to trade down or forego purchases, one-third of Chinese mobile-phone shoppers cited feelings of guilt as their reason for doing so. Similarly, one in five Indian consumers who planned to trade down or forego purchases of large domestic appliances said their main reason was that it didn\u0026rsquo;t feel right to spend, given the current social context. It remains to be seen whether this sentiment will change in the coming months. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Digital shopping accelerated, but physical stores retain appeal\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 crisis has naturally shifted consumers toward digital shopping and engagement channels. Yet the findings show uneven rates of acceleration across various types of online channels. Responses suggest that multicategory online marketplaces could be poised to gain the most momentum in the coming months, with the largest increase in net usage intent of any channels tested in the survey. But significantly larger shares of respondents in India and Indonesia said they expect to increase their use of their preferred platforms after the COVID-19 pandemic than said the same about other online platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, respondents also expressed the desire to return to physical stores\u0026mdash;particularly to shop for apparel in Indonesia, and mobile phones and small and large domestic appliances in India. In India, we see a higher stated intent to visit exclusive-brand stores than multibrand stores. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eImplications for businesses\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThriving in the post-COVID-19 future will ultimately require changes in how companies in these sectors think about staying relevant to consumers while managing increased operational complexity as well as potential delays in the rebound of demand and customer traffic. Combined with sales migration toward online channels and the renewed focus on value, these changes could contribute to margin compression. Moreover, there are certain behaviors that are likely to shift fundamentally, requiring reconsideration of the consumer proposition and companies\u0026rsquo; go-to-market strategy and operating model. Based on our research, there are five actions that companies can take now to prepare for the next normal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e1. Don\u0026rsquo;t just reopen: Rethink your store\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies have already invested significant time and effort to enforce new safety protocols and operating procedures as lockdowns ease. However, online acceleration will require a fundamental reevaluation of the role that stores still play for consumers in the next normal and how to ensure a delightful experience. Survey responses show that shoppers appreciate the \u0026ldquo;touch and feel experience\u0026rdquo; of physical stores. As stores enable product interaction while also generating traffic for e-commerce sales, the traditional way of looking at individual-store profit-and-loss statements might need to change. Also, it is important to consider how this role can be accomplished with a \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-stores-for-retails-next-normal\"\u003esimplified and more flexible store operation\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis entails reimagining end-to-end consumer engagement on digital channels and seamlessly linking online and offline experiences to radically accelerate in-store omnichannel integration. Companies that are both digital and offline, rather than one or the other, will be better positioned in the days ahead\u0026mdash;especially if they can use both to create a mutually reinforcing customer ecosystem. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. Earn and maintain consumers\u0026rsquo; trust\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe survey results indicate a \u0026ldquo;flight to safety\u0026rdquo; toward trusted brands, potentially accentuated by an environment of uncertainty and inability to test or experience products before buying them. Moreover, with the COVID-19 crisis affecting incomes and savings, respondents seem to be more cautious in their brand choices. Companies with high brand scores can further grow their presence and business by communicating reliability and instilling further trust in the brand. For new and niche players, communicating reasons to trust, and ensuring a \u0026ldquo;first-time right\u0026rdquo; product experience, could become more important than ever.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e3. Radiate value\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs shoppers look to purchase items that meet their criteria for value, it will be paramount for businesses to be able to immediately communicate to visitors to an online channel or store how their products fulfill these criteria. This entails rethinking which \u0026ldquo;star products\u0026rdquo; to highlight, as well as reconsidering overall product assortment and promotional calendars to effectively lower the customer hurdle by highlighting relevant products and offers, and by offering accessible entry price points. As we saw earlier, however, the concept of \u0026ldquo;value\u0026rdquo; can differ significantly by segment. Hence, executing this well requires a strong understanding of customer segmentation that enables a personalized approach. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, as consumers search for the best deals\u0026mdash;and retailers face overstock from lockdowns\u0026mdash;companies can benefit from being nimble amid a heightened promotional environment. Doing so may require adopting a rapid \u0026ldquo;test and learn\u0026rdquo; approach so they can quickly pivot to determine the most compelling offers for various customer segments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e4.
